text:
EDITORIAL NOTES.

It appears from a parliamentary return made by the British Government that the total number of persons killed in Ireland during the last four years was thirty-one, of whom seven were killed in 1883. The amount of compensation awarded to the heirs of the victims was £15,000. The amount to be paid to the relatives of those who were killed or injured is fixed by the Lord Lieutenant and is rated at £200 per case, although the family of the deceased in which the injury is done. It will be seen therefore, that Ireland does not get all her amends for nothing.

Spain seems to have a better mode of putting her discontented criminals to death than have some other countries. In Spain, the prisoners are executed by firing squad, and the bullets used are specially designed for this purpose. They are made of lead, and are pointed at both ends. When the prisoner is shot, the bullets pass through his body and explode inside, causing instant death.

The Woman Physician.

There is a great medical work for women doctors. Every woman physician who makes a study of this book will find it invaluable. It contains practical advice on how to treat various ailments, as well as information on how to care for oneself and one's family.

CHOERA.

This dreadfully epidemic is among the most dangerous diseases known to man. It is caused by a bacillus which is extremely contagious and can be spread easily through contact with infected persons or contaminated water. The symptoms include fever, vomiting, diarrhea, and dehydration. Treatment involves administering fluids and antibiotics to prevent complications such as shock and kidney failure.

PUBLIC NOTICE.

All persons are hereby notified that it is now possible to purchase land in the district of Dundurn, near the town of Dundurn. The land is being sold without authority by public auction, and anyone interested should apply to the Interior Minister for details.

CORRESPONDENCE.

LOUIS RIEL VISIT.

Louis Riel visited Prince Albert on July 18, 1884. He discussed the situation in the North-West Territories with Prime Minister Macdonald. Louis Riel expressed his concern about the treatment of the Métis people and the government's actions regarding the Red River Rebellion.
